importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the swearing-in ceremony of the new military leader, marking the official transition of power in Madagascar following a coup.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the youth-led protests occurred and culminated in the military takeover, indicating the timeline of political unrest and transition.

keyTakeAways: A military coup in Madagascar led by Army Colonel Michael Randrianirina resulted in the overthrow of President Andry Rajoelina.
Randrianirina was sworn in as president at the High Constitutional Court in Antananarivo, amid significant public and military support.
The coup followed three weeks of youth-led protests over water, electricity, cost of living, and corruption, which had resulted in at least 22 deaths.
The United Nations and African Union condemned the takeover as unconstitutional, and Madagascar was suspended from the African Union.
Randrianirina, previously imprisoned for an attempted mutiny, claimed the military action was to 'take responsibility as citizens and patriots' to save the country.
The new military government will govern for 18 months to two years before holding elections, delaying democratic transitions for youth voters.
The coup has sparked international concern over the erosion of democratic norms and the potential use of youth protests as a pretext for power grabs.

namedEntities.name: Madagascar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in East Africa, located on the Indian Ocean, with a population of around 30 million.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Madagascar is the setting of the political crisis, where a military coup overthrew the government and led to international condemnation and a suspension from the African Union.

namedEntities.name: Col. Michael Randrianirina
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An army colonel and commander of the CAPSAT unit who led the military coup and was sworn in as president.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the coup, transitioning from military obscurity to national leadership, and justifying his actions as a response to youth-led demands for change.

namedEntities.name: President Andry Rajoelina
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The previous president of Madagascar, ousted in the coup and now in hiding.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was the target of the coup and symbolizes the ousted democratic leadership, with his removal marking the end of his presidency and the beginning of military rule.

namedEntities.name: High Constitutional Court
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The judicial body in Madagascar where the swearing-in ceremony of the new president took place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was the official venue for the inauguration, though its legitimacy was challenged by claims of judicial intimidation and illegitimacy.

namedEntities.name: United Nations (UN)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international organization that condemned the coup as unconstitutional.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UN's condemnation highlights the global concern over the legitimacy of the military takeover and the violation of democratic principles.

namedEntities.name: African Union (AU)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional organization that suspended Madagascar from its membership.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The AU's rejection of the coup underscores the regional political stance against unconstitutional change of government in Madagascar.

namedEntities.name: European Union (EU)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international body that called for democratic restoration through national dialogue.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The EU's involvement signals external diplomatic pressure to restore democratic processes and prevent further authoritarian drift.

namedEntities.name: CAPSAT
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An elite military unit under Colonel Randrianirina's command.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It played a key role in the military action, with one soldier reportedly killed during clashes with loyal security forces.

namedEntities.name: Emmanuel Rabemanantsoa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A young Madagascan participant in the youth-led protests.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the voice of the youth movement that initiated the protests, criticizing the previous government's failure to address social issues.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Madagascar, Army Colonel Michael Randrianirina led a military coup that ousted President Andry Rajoelina, who fled into hiding after violence and protests over water, electricity, and corruption. Randrianirina was sworn in as president at the High Constitutional Court, amid claims of judicial illegitimacy and international condemnation from the United Nations and African Union. The military government plans to rule for 18 months to two years before elections, delaying democratic transition. The coup followed weeks of youth-led protests, raising global concerns about democratic backsliding and the misuse of public unrest for power grabs.
title: Madagascar Military Coup: Colonel Randrianirina Sworn In as President After Youth Protests
